title: Fan Duct for Luminar Products EX0001 filament extruder

description.text:
This duct is for the Luminar Products EX0001 Super Extruder when printing PLA material.  
The fan duct mounts onto the extruder cooling fan for the extruder block.  A second fan 
is mounted below and is ducted to the extrusion area.

The part is printed flat on the stage.  It prints rather easily.  The upper 60mm fan 
mounting holes will need to be drilled out for #8 screws. I used flat head wood screws 
to mount the lower 60mm fan.
I found this duct works great when printing PLA material.

author: goldmole

title: Printrboard Cage for Printrbot Simple with Tower

description.text: I got tired of squeezing my fingers in to work on the printrboard, particularly after I installed the Tower option for my Printrbot Simple.  So I cut out a big panel on the tower and inverted the board.  However this left it exposed to being bumped.  So I designed this cage, cage holder, and cage lock to protect it from being pumped into.
Print the Cover, 4 CoverHolder's, and CoverLock.  Measure and CAREFULLY drill holes for the 4 holders and lock.  Mount holders, lock , insert cage, lock it in place, and enjoy.

title: 2014 San Francisco Bay Area Maker Faire Kiosk Design Challenge Contest Entry

description.text:
Silly thingiverse!  The triangle should stand up, not balance on one edge.  
My vision is three portrait-mounted 55" TVs with capacitive touch surfaces.  Think super giant iPads.  Each one connects to a Raspberry Pi and displays an interactive map of the venue.  The map calls out where you are.  After a period without being touched it can play an animation, zoom to default coordinates, or more.  If given the event schedule it can call out "walk this way!  in 10 minutes there's a thing happening!"  
The three identical panels can be flat packed for storage.  All electronics and wiring are deliberately made explicit to educate young users, but they don't have to be.  The panels can be run individually or stood in a triangle.  BOM with quick google price search shows all wood and electronics within budget.  (better prices in the US and with more searching?)  
I don't have the software to run on the RPI.  Shame!  I'm sure it can be done, but I don't have the time.

Cut three identical panels from the provided design.  Mount TVs, cap screens, and RPIs to the outward face.  Wire, install software, and run.  Rope is used to tie the three sides together like giant shoelaces.  
Could display a jailed web browser running Google maps or a home-rolled map program (not provided by me)  
For storage, use the 1/2 nuts and bolts to attach the three panels into a single "block" - the bottom panel faces up and the next two panels face down.  To protect each TV, A piece of foam or bubble wrap between layers is recommended, and be sure to add a "FRAGILE - DO NOT STACK" sticker to the back of each panel.  
The BOM also includes an estimate for a full sized vynyl overlay.  A graphi designer could whip up something colorful to indicate this is Information booth, what are the components doing, it's OK to touch, etc.

title: Conversion rodamientos cama a casquillos de bronce, i3 Version Metacrilato

Stylus mounting head for the Ultimaker, that turns a 3D printer into a single pen plotter.
May also be useful for mounting other lightweight tools.

Print two of the PrintHeadClip parts.
Print one each of the StylusBracket and StylusClamp parts.
Clean out all holes with 3mm drill bit.
Glue pieces of inner tube rubber into clamp angles for better grip.
Assemble with three 3mmx10mm bolts and nuts.
Tighten upper and lower bolts completely, with parts at 90Â°.
Mount pencil or pen in bracket and tighten center bolt to fix the clamp.
Clip upper and lower print head clips onto the Ultimaker print head threaded rods.

comments.text: Fun to make, or see it in action. But in what way does it defeat a inktjet desktop printer that can easily hande A4 paper size?
comments.author: mikedeklerk

comments.text: It trumps an inkjet in that it (in principle) can hold other scribing tools besides pens, for example exacto knives, wood burning tools, engraving tools, milling cutters, etc. This weak little attachment would have a tough time holding heavy tools, but I wanted to prove out the workflow before committing more hardware effort.

title: TwirlyBird - Adjustable blade pitch hand helicopter

description.text: This a flying helicopter toy which has adjustable pitch of the blades.  It is rather heavy when printed and is difficult to get to fly by hand (can't get it to spin fast enough by hand). The best method to get it to fly is to wrap a string around the stem, place in a PVC pipe and pull the cord gently to get the needed rotational speed.

For the best results, I used Cura as a slicer and printed the rotors with the teardrop shape on the bed. I used a bottom/top layer thickness of 6mm so that the tear drop and stem would be solid plastic. 20% infill is plenty to get lots of strength, I've bashed the toy into several things when its flying and it still survived. Everything else should be printed 100% infill, especially the stem, for the needed strength (and weight at the bottom for stability). I had to do some filing on the rotor shafts to get them to fit into the slot gears, but not very much.
Assembly is a bit tricky. One has to place the small gear in between the two slot gears with the key-ways at the bottom (key-ways of the slot gears) and then insert the entire assembly into the gearbox. Once in, the rotors can be slid into place (point part of the teardrop is pointing up). Once the rotors are in, they can be rotated and the cotter pins put into the slots. These cotter pins are important, they prevent the rotors from popping out and hitting you in the face!! (A feature I had to add after getting hit a few times). One also needs to glue the stem into the gearbox (I used Elmer's white glue so I could remove it with hot water if I needed to disassemble the toy).
I will be adding a launching tube soon (to hold the Twirlybird when using a ripcord) to the list of parts.

remixed_from.author: WingedPower
remixed_from.title: Perforated Boards for Circuit Prototyping [ Round Holes ]

title: Perforated Boards for Circuit Prototyping [ Square Holes ]

description.text:
Various sized perforated boards that can be 3d printed and used for wire wrap prototyping. Note, since this is using FDM style printing material, soldering is a no-no. Conductive glue/ink/epoxies are fine. Wire wrapping is also fine, and is the intended use of these boards. Pregenerated STL files:
  • 0.1" (2.54mm) hole spacing
  • 0.042" (1.0668mm) hole diameter (may differ from printer to printer)
  • 0.062" (1.6mm) board thickness
    • Providing boards rendered in different dimensions:
  • 4"x4" (5MB file. You've been warned!)
  • 2"x1"
  • 1"x1"
    • Update: Added customizer options to the open scad file. You can now have Thingiverse generate boards of any dimension you want! Woot! Note, it took 24 minutes for the customizer to generate the 4x4 rendering. I tried 8x8 and it timed out. Just an FYI. If you need larger boards, then definitely download the openscad file, change the variables, and render it locally. Options:
  • board size
  • hole spacing
  • hole diameters
  • square holes or round holes

• Download the STL
  • Slice the STL (0.2mm layer height is fine)
  • Print the STL
  • Use the printed board!

comments.text: A coldheat sodering iron works fine when printed in abs

comments.text: Note, between the square and round hole versions, the square version renders much faster in openscad.

title: His and Hers Square Wedding Bands v1.0

description.text:
Our real matching wedding bands. Square outside, circle inside. Perfect fit around our ring fingers. There is also an aesthetic indent running along the middle of the ring. The "hers" band is thinner and more rounded for a delicate look. His: (in) 0.827w x 0.197d x 0.827h
(cm) 2.1w x 0.5d x 2.1h
Hers: (in) 0.738 w x 0.118 d x 0.738 h
(cm) 1.874 w x 0.3 d x 1.874 h It all started in SolidWorks. It was prototyped using a Makerbot Replicator 2 in pla to check the sizes (about 20 minutes for 2 rings). Then we sent the files to Shapeways and printed with their new premium silver option (~$50 each). We'll keep iterating and improving the design through the years and experiment with different material options as they become available. Collaborative project with http://www.thingiverse.com/Benjaminjaninja who shared his design and Solidworks expertise.

Files created using SolidWorks. Original design files and stl files available for download. Customize it, print it out, engrave it, wear it, love it. **Parameter Defaults***
Change the inner diameters of the ring noting that the wall edge isn't too thin. You can also play with the band thickness. It is currently a ring size 4.75mm for "hers" and options of 7.75mm, 8mm, and 8.25mm for "his".

comments.text: What paint did you use to make this silver and how long did the paint hold up to wearing it?  Thanks for sharing!
comments.author: brandonros

comments.text: Hi Brandon! I sent the file to Shapeways and actually printed it using real Silver. I had printed a prototype in ABS plastic just to double check the size (as seen in one of the pictures). In the past, I have used spray paint for coloring makerbot pieces, which worked fine and has never chipped or worn off. Just remember to paint outside and allow time for it to dry. G'luck!
comments.author: brandonros

remixed_from.author: joo
remixed_from.title: OpenDive Lasercut - VR Goggles for Android

description.text:
A mildly steampunk laser cut version of Durovis OpenDive VR goggles.  
This version is a bit more stable and less shaky than joo's, and does not require any 3d printed parts.  
Originally designed for Nexus 4, tested with Nexus 5, should be compatible with all devices of similar size.

First, you'll need the Durovis lens and strap kit from amazon.de (http://www.amazon.de/dp/B00COO64IC). It costs 6.99 EUR and its worth every cent. Laser cut the source file from 3mm MDF, with the red parts cut out first. Use M4 bolts to put it all together, and a bit of glue to hold the lenses to the frame. The "flatter" side of the lenses should face the eyes. Use rubber bands to hold the phone in place, and to keep the lens contraptions in place. Do not tie the bolts on the sides too tightly so you are able to adjust the lenses as needed. The whole thing cost me about 12 EUR, and it is quite fun to play with. Enjoy! Let me know if it works! :)

comments.text: I made this by printing it out and cutting it out to make a pattern. From there I taped the pattern onto a plastic sheet that I cut from a garbage can I found in the dumpster. Once on, I used a soldering iron to cut the pieces out of plastic and a xacto knife to clean it up I used the soldering iron again to weld all the pieces together. Worked out pretty well, now I just need to add a strap. Thanks for posting these plans.
comments.author: 00meat
